title: Fuck You: from the Liz Taylor Series (after Bert Stern)

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of acrylic and composition leaf on canvas.

description:
Kathe Burkhart is an artist and writer who uses images and text to, in her words, “articulate a radical female subject.” She considers this confrontational, sensual work to be the first fully realized canvas in her Liz Taylor Series, ongoing since 1982. The series of large-scale, richly saturated paintings combines appropriated portraits of actress Elizabeth Taylor (here, a shot of her as Cleopatra, taken by Bert Stern for Vogue magazine in 1962) with profane language, shattering both female stereotypes and conventions of representation. Taylor was a controversial feminist figure throughout her career, conveying equal parts bravura, sexual power, and vulnerability. Burkhart—collapsing the genres of portraiture and self-portraiture—treated the actress as a surrogate figure
for her own life in the diary-like narrative series.
medium_display: Acrylic and composition leaf on canvas
exhibition_history:
Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions, Emblem, Oct. 10–Nov. 11, 1984.

Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions, TV Generations (co-curated by John Baldessari and Bruce Yonemoto), Feb. 2–Apr. 4, 1986.	

New York, Greathouse Gallery, 1988.

Chicago, Feature, Inc., Kathe Burkhart: Paintings from the Liz Taylor Series, June 1–25, 1988.

Kunsthalle Frieberg, Germany, Kathe Burkhart: The Liz Taylor Series, Mar. 13–May 16, 2016.
provenance_text: Created at the California Institute of the Arts in 1984; artist 1984–1991; consigned to Hudson (of Feature, Inc., New York) by 1991; given to an unnamed owner, New York, in 2004; given to an unnamed owner, Brooklyn, in 2004; given back to the artist in 2013; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, November 2016.

input: Fuck You: from the Liz Taylor Series (after Bert Stern)
